definitions.definition: to move through the air, using wings

examples.text: Penguins can't fly.
A stork flew slowly past.
A wasp had flown in through the window.
Geese fly south in the fall.

definitions.definition: to move through air or space
definitions.sensetop: fly (from A) (to B)fly (to B) (from A)+ adv./prep.

examples.text: They were on a plane flying from London to New York.
Lufthansa fly to La Paz from Frankfurt.
Enemy planes **fly overhead**.
to fly at the speed of sound
The aircraft was declared fully functional and fit to fly.

definitions.definition: to travel in an aircraft or a spacecraft

examples.text: Is this the first time that you've flown?
I'm flying to Hong Kong tomorrow.
I was flying home to visit my family.
I always fly business class.
We're flying KLM.

definitions.definition: to control an aircraft, etc. in the air

examples.text: He's learning to fly.
a pilot trained to fly large passenger planes
children flying kites
She's trained to fly passenger planes, not military jets.
You'll have to fly the helicopter over some dangerous territory.

definitions.definition: to transport goods or passengers in a plane

examples.text: The stranded tourists were finally flown home.
He had flowers specially flown in for the ceremony.
Orders were given to fly the prisoners to the US.

definitions.definition: to move through the air for a particular distance; to travel over an ocean or area of land in an aircraft

examples.text: Some birds fly huge distances when they migrate.
Who was the first person to fly the Atlantic?
Only four airlines are currently allowed to fly transatlantic routes from Heathrow.

definitions.definition: to go or move quickly

examples.text: The train was flying along.
She gasped and her hand flew to her mouth.
It's late—I must fly.

definitions.definition: to move suddenly and with force

examples.text: A large stone came flying in through the window.
Several people were hit by flying glass.
David gave the door a kick and it flew open.

definitions.definition: to seem to pass very quickly

examples.text: Doesn't time fly?
Summer has just flown by.

definitions.definition: if a flag flies, or if you fly it, it is displayed, for example on a pole (= a long piece of wood or metal)

examples.text: **Flags were flying** at half mast on all public buildings.
to fly the Stars and Stripes

definitions.definition: to move around freely

examples.text: hair flying in the wind

definitions.definition: to be talked about by many people
to escape from somebody/something

examples.text: Both suspects have flown the country.

definitions.definition: to be successful

examples.text: It remains to be seen whether his project will fly.

definitions.definition: to hit a ball high into the air
in a straight line

examples.text: The villages are no more than a mile apart as the crow flies.

definitions.definition: the wanted person has escaped
to act without careful thought and without a plan that you have made in advance, hoping that you will be lucky and be successful
to escape from a place
to show your support for your country, an organization or an idea to encourage or persuade others to do the same
to be successful

examples.text: British cinema has been flying high recently, winning several coveted awards.

definitions.definition: to oppose or be the opposite of something that is usual or expected

examples.text: Such a proposal is flying in the face of common sense.

definitions.definition: to become suddenly very angry
to test out public opinion on a subject

examples.text: The company is flying a kite to see if this plan provokes any interest.

definitions.definition: to become able to fly and leave its nest
to leave home and live somewhere else

examples.text: Her children have flown the nest.

definitions.definition: to suddenly start saying or doing something that does not seem to be connected to what has gone before

examples.text: He never sticks to the point but keeps going off at a tangent.
Laura’s mind went off at a tangent.

definitions.definition: to suddenly become very angry

examples.text: He seems to fly off the handle about the slightest thing these days.

definitions.definition: to stop existing; to disappear completely

examples.text: As soon as the kids arrived, order went out of the window.

definitions.definition: to fall, especially as a result of not seeing something under your feet

examples.text: Someone's going to go flying if you don't pick up these toys.

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody to go away and stop annoying you or interfering
to represent your country or organization

examples.text: Our exporters keep the flag flying at international trade exhibitions.

definitions.definition: to attack somebody by hitting them or speaking angrily to them

examples.text: He let fly at me with his fist.
She let fly with a stream of abuse.

definitions.definition: used to show that you do not believe something will ever happen

examples.text: ‘With a bit of luck, we'll be finished by the end of the year.’ ‘Yes, and pigs might fly!’

definitions.definition: time seems to pass very quickly

examples.text: How time flies! I've got to go now.
Time has flown since the holiday began.

wordOrigin: verb Old English flēogan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch vliegen and German fliegen, also to fly, the insect.
